newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan president says sorry for worsening crime.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan president says sorry for worsening crime.

text.p: Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui on Friday apologised for a worsening crime problem highlighted by the kidnap and murder of a popular actress's daughter.
"As head of state, I express my most sincere apology for the worsening social law and order," Lee's chief of staff, Huang Kun-huei, quoted the president as saying
"The government will take full responsibility," Lee was quoted as saying.
Lee made the apology during a security summit attended by top government officials and military leaders intended to calm public fears over crime on this affluent island of 21 million people.
The meeting was held ahead of a planned march by more than 20,000 people in Taipei on Sunday to protest what is perceived as the government's inability to stamp out crime.
In a crime that has shocked the nation, police on Monday found the body of 17-year-old Pai Hsiao-yen, daughter of actress Pai Ping-ping, floating naked in a river.
Police said the kidnappers, who remained at large, had bound and strangled the teenager and tossed her into the river with weights attached to her body.
The murder prompted calls for the resignation of Vice President Lien Chan, who doubles as premier, and other officials for failing to maintain social stability.

The island's police chief and other officals said they were willing to take responsibility for the situation but the president said the priority was on solving the case, Huang told a news conference at the meeting.
Pai's murder followed a string of high-profile violent crimes in recent months.
In November, two gunmen broke into the home of northern Taoyuan County magistrate Liu Pang-yu and killed eight people, including Liu, in gangland-style executions.
One week later, women's rights activist Peng Wan-ju was raped and stabbed to death in southern Taiwan. Police found 35 stab wounds in her naked body.
Interior Minister Lin Feng-cheng acknowledged in December that Taiwan's social order had deteriorated to a shocking level, with the crime rate soaring by 80 percent from 1990 to 1996.
Anti-crime activists said the murder of Pai Hsiao-yen was the latest example of how the government failed to protect its people.

"Pai's case was the last straw. And we can no longer tolerate the government's inability to stamp out crime," said Feng Hsien-hsien, executive director of the Peng Wan-ju Foundation, set up after the murder of the feminist.
"This was why we decided to join forces to stage a large-scale march on Sunday to demand that the government improve law and order in Taiwan," she told Reuters.
